review.title: Corpora Preparation and Stopword List Generation for Arabic data in Social Network
review.abstract: This paper proposes a methodology to prepare corpora in Arabic language from online social network (OSN) and review site for Sentiment Analysis (SA) task. The paper also proposes a methodology for generating a stopword list from the prepared corpora. The aim of the paper is to investigate the effect of removing stopwords on the SA task. The problem is that the stopwords lists generated before were on Modern Standard Arabic (MSA) which is not the common language used in OSN. We have generated a stopword list of Egyptian dialect and a corpus-based list to be used with the OSN corpora. We compare the efficiency of text classification when using the generated lists along with previously generated lists of MSA and combining the Egyptian dialect list with the MSA list. The text classification was performed using Na\"ive Bayes and Decision Tree classifiers and two feature selection approaches, unigrams and bigram. The experiments show that the general lists containing the Egyptian dialects words give better performance than using lists of MSA stopwords only.

metadata.title: Corpora Preparation and Stopword List Generation for Arabic data in Social Network

sections.text: The aim of the work is to investigate the impact of the removal of stopwords on the SA task. The problem is that the previously created stopword lists were based on modern standard Arabic (MSA), which is not the usual language in the OSN. We have created a stopword list of the Egyptian dialect and a corpus-based list for the OSN corpora. We compare the efficiency of text classification when using the created lists together with previously created lists of the MSA and combine the Egyptian dialect list with the MSA list. Text classification was performed using Naïve Bayes and Decision Tree classifiers and two approaches to selecting characteristics, unigrams and bigrams. Experiments show that the general lists containing the Egyptian dialect words perform better than the lists of MSA stopwords alone.

sections.heading: 2. Methodology
sections.text: The aim of our study is to process data from Twitter, Facebook and a review page on the same topic in Arabic for South Africa. We selected a hot topic for the films recently shown in cinemas for the last festival in August 2014, which were: "The Blue Elephant" means "The Third World War"; "The Blue Elephant" means "Made in Egypt"; "The Third World War" means "Official Marriage." We downloaded related tweets from Twitter, comments from the Facebook pages of some films and user reviews from the review site elcinema.com. Tweets were downloaded via the films, using Twitter's regular search, as many of the pages that retrieve tweets are closed, such as (searchHash, topsy).

sections.heading: 3. Stopword list Generation
sections.text: The most common English words that do not affect the meaning of a sentence are such as "a," "the," "of...." Removing stop words reduces the body size without losing important information. In some corpus-specific words, the meaning of the word "movie" in a movie review corpus could not be affected, but means something in the news corpus. This word could be considered a stop word when analyzing the corpus of movie reviews. The common strategy for determining a stop word list is to calculate the frequency of occurrence of each word in the document collection, and then take the most common words. The selected terms are often filtered by hand according to their semantic content relative to the domain of the indexed documents and marked as a stop word list. The English stop word list is generic and contains 127 words such as (all, just being,....). To generate the stop word generally for Arabic, they are specified in these three steps.

sections.heading: 3.1 Calculating words frequency
sections.text: The rating corpus gives 3781 unique words, the Facebook corpus 1451 unique words and the Twitter corpus 1160 unique words. This shows that despite the number of ratings, they are much less than the OSN corpus, but they are lexically rich. After they are combined together and the duplicates removed, the list of common words consists of 4818 words. Then we calculated the frequency of occurrence of each word from the list of all words in the three corpus together.

sections.heading: 3.2 The validity of words to be a stopword
sections.text: To create a general list of Egyptian stopwords, we have taken the most common 200 words and removed the semantically recognized words, which are likely nouns and verbs. Then, to create a general list of Egyptian dialects, we have added each word of the Egyptian dialect to the most common words, which are semantically meaningless. To confirm whether the word is a stopword or not; if the word is an MSA word, we check its existence in the MSA stopword list. If it does not exist, we check its corresponding meaning in the English stopword list. sections.heading: 4.1 Data Annotation
sections.text: Ratings from the review page were previously rated by the site. They received a grade of 1 to 10. Ratings greater than 5 are rated as positive and less than 5 as negative. Ratings equal to 5 are neutral. We commented on the ratings according to the rating of the site. In the OSN data, we commented on the corpora manually. The manual comment was more reliable because the person analyzing the data is so far better than the machine. Table 1 shows the number of positive, negative and neutral reviews, comments and tweets resulting from comments.

sections.heading: 4.2 Classifiers Preparation
sections.text: We trained Naive Bayes and Decision Tree Classifiers. The classifiers were performed with the nltk 2.0 toolkit. There are some parameters that can be entered into the DT classifier to improve accuracy or reduce training time [25]. The parameters are: -entropy cutoff: used during the tree grafting process. If the entropy of the probability distribution of the label selection in the tree is greater than the entropy cutoff, then the tree is further refined. But if the entropy is lower than the entropy cutoff, then the tree grafting is stopped. Entropy is the uncertainty of the result. If the entropy approaches the 1.0, uncertainty increases and vice versa. Higher values of entropy cutoff reduce both the accuracy and the training time. It was set to "0.8." Depth of the tree to control the depth of the cutoff.

sections.heading: 4.3 Feature Selection
sections.text: There are two features selection (FS) techniques used in the test: -Unigram: treats the documents as Bag of Words (BOWs), which build a word presence function from all words in an instance. -Bigram: is the same as a one-off, but finds two words.

sections.heading: 3.5 Results
sections.text: We have conducted many experiments to test the effect of removing stopwords from different lists using the combination of two FS techniques and two classifiers with the three different corpora. We have performed the tests to determine 75% of the total number of data in each corpus for training and 25% for testing data. The default accuracy was used to evaluate the performance for each test. Accuracy is defined as: the ratio of the number of correctly classified reviews, comments and tweets to the total number of data. Table 2 contains the results of the various tests we performed. The accuracy of the ratings is relatively high as the number of ratings is low and the data highly unbalanced. Accuracy decreases when using corpus-based list on the lexically rich ratings, and the general lists including Egyptian dialects provide better results than the others. The timing does not change much, but in general it decreases when removing stopwords. The DT delivers better results than Facebook's extreme because it is NT-B.
